required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: The Impact of an Acute Bout of Exercise on Children's Eating Behaviors

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this project is to examine the effects of an acute bout of exercise on children's energy intake over the course of a day. Previous studies in adolescents and adults have shown exercise to be effective in decreasing short-term energy intake, with some variability. Individual characteristics such as habitual physical activity and psychological factors may influence the effect of exercise on energy intake, but these factors have yet to be examined. The investigators have assembled a multi-disciplinary team of researchers, with expertise in eating behavior, exercise, psychology, and clinical research in order to examine these questions. First, the investigators will examine the difference in energy intake at lunch, snack, and dinner meals in response to 30 minutes of imposed exercise compared to 30 minutes of rest. Second, the investigators will collect objective measures of children's habitual physical activity, child characteristics (body composition, eating behavior traits), and individual responses to the controlled exercise bout. The investigators can then examine both group and individual differences in the energy intake response to exercise. Children (ages 9-12) will be tested over the course of three visits. The key outcome will be differences in energy intake in response to exercise vs. rest. Secondary outcomes include the influence of differences in habitual physical activity, personal characteristics, and responses to the exercise bout on children's energy intake. The long term goal of this line of research is to understand the mechanisms behind the interaction between exercise and energy intake. The translational potential of this research will be to inform personalized childhood obesity prevention strategies in children at risk for overweight.

primary_outcome.time_frame: Collected at week 1 of the study
primary_outcome.description: Food intake is measured at objective laboratory test-meals as the difference between the pre-meal and post-meal weights of individual food items served. Weight of food is converted to energy in kilocalories based on nutrition facts label information.

primary_outcome.time_frame: Collected at week 2 or 3 (randomized) of the study
primary_outcome.description: Food intake is measured at objective laboratory test-meals as the difference between the pre-meal and post-meal weights of individual food items served. Weight of food is converted to energy in kilocalories based on nutrition facts label information.

primary_outcome.time_frame: Collected at week 2 or 3 (randomized) of the study
primary_outcome.description: Food intake is measured at objective laboratory test-meals as the difference between the pre-meal and post-meal weights of individual food items served. Weight of food is converted to energy in kilocalories based on nutrition facts label information.

primary_outcome.time_frame: Collected in the laboratory at week 1, 2, and 3, and at home for one week between the 2nd and 3rd laboratory visits
Collected at week 2 or 3 (randomized) of the study

primary_outcome.measure: Activity-related energy expenditure - Sedentary control day
primary_outcome.time_frame: Collected at week 2 or 3 (randomized) of the study

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Collected at week 1 of the study
secondary_outcome.description: YMCA submaximal cycle ergometer test - American College of Sports Medicine

secondary_outcome.measure: Exercise test performance (70% intensity) - Heart rate
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Collected at week 2 or 3 (randomized) of the study
secondary_outcome.description: Measured by Polar Heart Rate Monitor

secondary_outcome.measure: Exercise test performance (70% intensity) - Blood pressure
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Collected at week 2 or 3 (randomized) of the study
secondary_outcome.description: Measured by registered nurse or trained research assistant

secondary_outcome.measure: Exercise test performance (70% intensity) - Ratings of perceived exertion
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Collected at week 2 or 3 (randomized) of the study
Collected at week 2 or 3 (randomized) of the study
secondary_outcome.description: Children's completion of the full 30 minutes of 70% intensity exercise

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Collected at home for one week between the 2nd and 3rd laboratory visits
Collected at home for one week between the 2nd and 3rd laboratory visits

other_outcome.time_frame: Collected at week 1 and 2 of the study
other_outcome.description: Ratings of how much child likes specific foods used in the study test meals, completed on visual analog scales

other_outcome.time_frame: Collected at week 1 and 2 of the study
other_outcome.description: Ratings of how much child wants to eat specific foods used in the study test meals, completed on visual analog scales

other_outcome.time_frame: Collected at multiple time points during weeks 1, 2, and 3
other_outcome.description: Ratings of how full the child feels on a child friendly visual analog scale
Height in cm measured by stadiometer
Weight in kg by standard digital scale
Assessed by bioelectrical impedance analysis scale
Calculated from height, weight, age, sex
Calculated from height, weight, age, sex
Calculated from body fat percentage, weight, height
Calculated from fat mass, weight, height
Parent-reported questionnaire of habitual eating styles in children

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- English as a native language
- Reading at/above grade level
- Generally healthy
- Child is "normal weight" below the 85% age- and sex-specific BMI percentile
- Child has at least one biological parent classified as "overweight" or "obese" (â‰¥ 25 kg/m^2)
- Regularly eats breakfast
Exclusion Criteria:
- Contraindications to exercise testing (as defined by the American College of Sports Medicine)
- Medical conditions
- Psychiatric conditions
- Participation in competitive sports teams (year-round or more than 3 practices / week)
- Food allergies or other dietary restrictions
